channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: Digitization Unearths New Data From Cold War-Era Nuclear Test Films
item.description: March 16, 2017 - The U.S. conducted hundreds of atmospheric nuclear tests between 1945 and 1962 — and filmed them. A project to digitize those films has changed the analysis of the nuclear explosions themselves.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 16, 2017 - The U.S. conducted hundreds of atmospheric nuclear tests between 1945 and 1962 — and filmed them. A project to digitize those films has changed the analysis of the nuclear explosions themselves. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/16/520398342/digitization-unearths-new-data-from-cold-war-era-nuclear-test-films

item.title: How To Make Farmers Love Cover Crops? Pay Them
item.description: March 16, 2017 - New satellite images reveal that few Midwestern farmers are planting pollution-preventing "cover crops." In Maryland, though, farmers are doing it, thanks to hefty subsidies.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 16, 2017 - New satellite images reveal that few Midwestern farmers are planting pollution-preventing "cover crops." In Maryland, though, farmers are doing it, thanks to hefty subsidies. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/03/16/520281317/how-to-make-farmers-love-cover-crops-pay-them

item.title: Study: 'Urgent' Action Against Global Warming Needed To Save Coral Reefs
item.description: March 16, 2017 - After another major coral bleaching event, a new study has concluded that securing a future for coral reefs "ultimately requires urgent and rapid action to reduce global warming."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 16, 2017 - After another major coral bleaching event, a new study has concluded that securing a future for coral reefs "ultimately requires urgent and rapid action to reduce global warming." http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/16/520450521/study-urgent-action-against-global-warming-needed-to-save-coral-reefs

item.title: Groovy: Scientists Say They've Found The First Fluorescent Frog
item.description: March 16, 2017 - The South American polka dot tree frog initially appears unremarkable. But when researchers in Argentina shone an ultraviolet light on the frog, it glowed.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 16, 2017 - The South American polka dot tree frog initially appears unremarkable. But when researchers in Argentina shone an ultraviolet light on the frog, it glowed. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/16/520311715/groovy-scientists-say-theyve-found-the-first-fluorescent-frog

item.title: One Way To Force Down Drug Prices: Have The U.S. Exercise Its Patent Rights
item.description: March 16, 2017 - Some members of Congress say the U.S. government should use the patent rights it owns for any drugs that were developed with federal grants to drive down the prices of those drugs.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 16, 2017 - Some members of Congress say the U.S. government should use the patent rights it owns for any drugs that were developed with federal grants to drive down the prices of those drugs. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/16/520390026/one-way-to-force-down-drug-prices-have-the-u-s-exercise-its-patent-rights

item.title: Trump's Budget Slashes Climate Change Funding
item.description: March 16, 2017 - The White House's proposed federal budget cuts everything from research to regulation, and makes clear that the administration doesn't view climate change as a priority.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 16, 2017 - The White House's proposed federal budget cuts everything from research to regulation, and makes clear that the administration doesn't view climate change as a priority. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/16/520399205/trumps-budget-slashes-climate-change-funding

item.title: How One Of The World's Toughest Creatures Can Bring Itself Back To Life
item.description: March 16, 2017 - The tardigrade, a strange animal smaller than a grain of sand and with hooks for feet, can survive in a dried-up state for a decade. Its secret might help improve how drugs are shipped and stored.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 16, 2017 - The tardigrade, a strange animal smaller than a grain of sand and with hooks for feet, can survive in a dried-up state for a decade. Its secret might help improve how drugs are shipped and stored. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/16/519986839/how-one-of-the-worlds-toughest-creatures-can-bring-itself-back-to-life

item.title: Trump Administration Proposes Big Cuts In Medical Research
item.description: March 16, 2017 - The National Institutes of Health, which funds research in treatments and cures, could lose 20 percent of its budget under the administration's proposal. More money would go for addiction treatment.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 16, 2017 - The National Institutes of Health, which funds research in treatments and cures, could lose 20 percent of its budget under the administration's proposal. More money would go for addiction treatment. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/16/520390147/trump-administration-proposes-big-cuts-in-medical-research

item.title: Study Finds High Temperatures Killing Large Parts Of Great Barrier Reef
item.description: March 16, 2017 - A new study looks at coral bleaching in 2015-2016. Mia Hoogenboom was a co-author, who says warming ocean temperatures are killing sections of the Great Barrier Reef faster than researchers expected.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 16, 2017 - A new study looks at coral bleaching in 2015-2016. Mia Hoogenboom was a co-author, who says warming ocean temperatures are killing sections of the Great Barrier Reef faster than researchers expected. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/16/520364036/study-finds-high-temperatures-killing-large-parts-of-great-barrier-reef

item.title: Travel Ban Adds Stress To 'Match Week' For Some Doctors
item.description: March 16, 2017 - A medical residency program is the next training step for newly minted doctors, and awaiting "the match" can be tense. For some international students, Trump's travel ban has made that tension worse.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 16, 2017 - A medical residency program is the next training step for newly minted doctors, and awaiting "the match" can be tense. For some international students, Trump's travel ban has made that tension worse. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/16/520137303/travel-ban-adds-stress-to-match-week-for-some-doctors

item.title: 3 Women Blinded By Unproven Stem Cell Treatments
item.description: March 15, 2017 - Three patients were blinded after getting stem cells from fat at a Florida clinic. But a research study showed that induced pluripotent stem cells might someday help treat vision loss.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 15, 2017 - Three patients were blinded after getting stem cells from fat at a Florida clinic. But a research study showed that induced pluripotent stem cells might someday help treat vision loss. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/15/520118310/3-women-blinded-by-unproven-stem-cell-treatments

item.title: California Officials Pledge Not To Roll Back Fuel Efficiency Standards
item.description: March 15, 2017 - California officials have said they will not back off the fuel efficiency standards established under Obama, despite the Trump administration's plan to revisit those standards.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 15, 2017 - California officials have said they will not back off the fuel efficiency standards established under Obama, despite the Trump administration's plan to revisit those standards. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/15/520301645/california-officials-pledge-not-to-roll-back-fuel-efficiency-standards

item.title: Trump To Reopen Review Of Car Fuel Efficiency Standards
item.description: March 15, 2017 - President Trump announced he is reopening review of car fuel efficiency standards at a rally Wednesday in Michigan. But his claims that the standards are hurting the auto industry's bottom line come at a time when carmakers are enjoying record profits.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 15, 2017 - President Trump announced he is reopening review of car fuel efficiency standards at a rally Wednesday in Michigan. But his claims that the standards are hurting the auto industry's bottom line come at a time when carmakers are enjoying record profits. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/15/520301638/trump-to-reopen-review-of-car-fuel-efficiency-standards

item.title: Emails Reveal Monsanto's Tactics To Defend Glyphosate Against Cancer Fears
item.description: March 15, 2017 - Internal emails show Monsanto executives scrambling to counter a U.N. agency's finding that glyphosate, the chemical in Roundup, can cause cancer. One email proposed "ghost-writing" scientific papers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 15, 2017 - Internal emails show Monsanto executives scrambling to counter a U.N. agency's finding that glyphosate, the chemical in Roundup, can cause cancer. One email proposed "ghost-writing" scientific papers. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/03/15/520250505/emails-reveal-monsantos-tactics-to-defend-glyphosate-against-cancer-fears

item.title: Cancer Drug That Might Slow Parkinson's, Alzheimer's Headed For Bigger Tests
item.description: March 15, 2017 - In a preliminary study, the cancer drug nilotinib seemed to help patients with Parkinson's and dementia. Now two larger and more rigorous studies of the drug are under way.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 15, 2017 - In a preliminary study, the cancer drug nilotinib seemed to help patients with Parkinson's and dementia. Now two larger and more rigorous studies of the drug are under way. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/15/520170960/cancer-drug-that-might-slow-parkinson-s-alzheimer-s-headed-for-bigger-tests
